title: Re: Choose your lucky number!!
content:
Well, consider a and b to be the same number; in other words:
a = b.
That means:
a^2 = ab
Substract b^2 from both sides:
a^2 - b^2 = ab - b^2
You can rewrite that (don't know the proper English word):
(a-b)(a+b) = b(a-b)
Divide by (a-b) on both sides:
a+b = b
Since a = b, you can also say:
b+b = b
So:
2b = b
In other words:
2 = 1

Option 1 and 2 are identical.

Option 3 is just the sum of 2 and 1, which is the same as the sum of 2 and 2, obviously, so option 3 is identical to option 4.

Actually option 2 is the sum of 1 and 1, which is the same as the sum of 2 and 2, so option 2 is the same as option 4 as well, meaning option 1 through 3 are identical.

If 1 and 2 are identical, and 3 and 4 are identical, en 1 and 3 are also identical, the must really all be identical.

Finally option 5 is the sum of 3 and 2, but those are basically the same as 1.
That means 5 is identical to the sum of 1 and 1 as well, which would be 2, so 5 isn't really a different option either.
In other words, it doesn't matter what you choose.

title: Re: Choose your lucky number!!
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]So:
2b = b
In other words:
2 = 1[hr][/quote]Actually no, 2b = b doesn't mean 2 = 1, it means double a certain number still equals that number - you can't just remove the 'b' and expect to get the right answer. You have to replace the 'b' with an actual number, and the only actual number that fits that formula is zero. Hence b = 0, because 2 x 0 = 0, which means a = 0 as well. Nothing unusual there...

title: Re: Choose your lucky number!!
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Actually no, 2b = b doesn't mean 2 = 1, it means double a certain number still equals that number - you can't just remove the 'b' and expect to get the right answer.[hr][/quote]

You don't "just remove" the b, you divide by it on both sides.
As an alternative, assume b=10.
2x10=10, or 20=10.
You can now divide both sides by 10, and get 2=1.
Or if b=1, then 2x1=1, or 2=1, both sides divided by 1, and... uhm, still 2=1.
Maybe b is pi.
2x pi = pi, and you can then divide both sides by pi...
Mmm, pie!
Doesn't matter, it really does say that 2=1.
The flaw appeared earlier than that.

[quote]Quote:[hr]You have to replace the 'b' with an actual number, and the only actual number that fits that formula is zero. Hence b = 0, because 2 x 0 = 0, which means a = 0 as well. Nothing unusual there...[hr][/quote]

It's not an assignment where you need to figure out what b is; the b is just to try and hide the divide-by-zero thing Xky was talking about.
